questions.question: You walk into a meeting and instantly notice someone is upset, even though they’re smiling. This happens:
How accurately can you name what you’re feeling in the moment (not just “good” or “bad”)?
When a friend is venting, your usual response is:
choices: Listen fully and mirror their feelings before offering advice
Jump in with solutions right away
Wait for my turn to talk
Change the subject if it gets too heavy

questions.question: During an argument, you’re able to stay calm and notice your rising emotions before they take over:
You can usually tell the difference between someone being sarcastic versus genuinely kind:
choices: Yes, easily from tone and body language
I take everything at face value

questions.question: When you’ve hurt someone’s feelings (even unintentionally), you tend to:
choices: Only realize when they tell me

questions.question: How often do you adjust your behavior based on the emotional state of the people around you?
choices: All the time—I read the room

questions.question: Colleagues or friends would describe you as:
After a stressful day, you’re able to shift your mood instead of staying stuck in it:
choices: Yes, I have reliable ways to reset
I carry it with me for days

questions.question: You genuinely enjoy trying to understand why people feel and act the way they do:
choices: Not really—people should just say what they mean

score.high: Emotional Intelligence Superstar  You read people like open books and navigate feelings with ninja-level skill.
score.medium: Solid Emotional Radar  You’re tuned in most of the time—keep practicing and you’ll be elite.
score.low: Just Starting the Journey � baby steps You’re probably more logical than emotional (nothing wrong with that), but there’s huge growth ahead if you want it!
